summary: The text discusses the concept of Christ constantly being preceded by the mercy of God, highlighting how Jewish dispersion and their laws serve as a testament to Christ's existence. It advocates for the Jewish people not to be killed, but rather dispersed across various kingdoms, as exemplified by Titus and Vespasian. It calls for the conversion of the Jews, asking God to humble them by removing their pride and sins. The text criticizes the Jews for their false interpretations of the scriptures and lies about Christ. It envisions a time when the Jews will acknowledge their errors and become perfect and no longer blasphemous sinners, through divine judgment and conversion.
